body:
Requested by @laanwj in #8423 (which addresses some of these by upgrading packages).

I haven't found any CVEs for:
ccache 3.3.1 (latest)
Libevent 2.0.22 (latest)
Expat 2.2.0 (latest)
Fontconfig 2.12.1 (latest)
Qt 5.6.1 (latest is 5.7)
Freetype 2.6.3 (latest is 2.6.5)
Boost 1.59.0 (latest is 1.61.0)
Protobuf 2.6.3 (latest is 3.1.0)
Zeromq 4.1.5 (latest is 4.1.5)
Miniupnpc 2.0 (latest is 2.0)
qrencode 3.4.4 (latest is 3.4.4)

#### dbus 1.8.6, (latest is 1.10.10, which fixes these issues)
[CVE-2014-3635](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2014-3635) - Do not accept an extra fd in the padding of a cmsg message, which could lead to a 4-byte heap buffer overrun.
[CVE-2014-3636](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2014-3636) - Additionally, on Linux this prevents a second denial of service in which the dbus-daemon can be made to exceed the maximum number of fds per sendmsg() and disconnect the process that would have received them.
[CVE-2014-3637](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2014-3637) - Disconnect connections that still have a fd pending unmarshalling after a new configurable limit, pending_fd_timeout (defaulting to 150 seconds), removing the possibility of creating an abusive connection that cannot be disconnected by setting up a circular reference to a connection's file descriptor.
[CVE-2014-3638](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2014-3638) - Reduce default for maximum pending replies per connection from 8192 to 128, mitigating an algorithmic complexity denial-of-service attack.
[CVE-2014-3639](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2014-3639) - Reduce default for authentication timeout on the system bus from 30 seconds to 5 seconds, avoiding denial of service by using up all unauthenticated connection slots; and when all unauthenticated connection slots are used up, make new connection attempts block instead of disconnecting them.
[CVE-2015-0245](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2015-0245) - Do not allow non-uid-0 processes to send forged ActivationFailure messages. On Linux systems with systemd activation, this would allow a local denial of service: unprivileged processes could flood the bus with these forged messages, winning the race with the actual service activation and causing an error reply to be sent back when service auto-activation was requested. This does not prevent the real service from being started, so the attack only works while the real service is not running.
